trial_identification.studytitle: Pain processing in patients after severe burns versus a population of unaffected volunteers: a comparison
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Pain processing in patients after severe burns versus a population of unaffected volunteers: a comparison

interventions.interventions: Comparison of the information obtained from the non-traumatic nerve stimulation testing in burns patients to that of a group of matched controls who have also undergone identical nerve stimulation testing. The duration of testing is a single 60 minute session

primaryOutcome.outcome: Amount of electrical stimulation (in miivolt) required to first produce a sensation of pain as produced by a single twitch according to known physiological testing algorithms for evaluation of threshold

Amount of electrical stimulation (in miivolt) required to first produce a sensation of pain as produced by a single twitch according to known physiological testing algorithms for evaluation of threshold
primaryOutcome.timepoint: once off visit after burns group complete on healthy volunteers

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Measurement of wind up by specific patterns of stimulation using elctrophysiological testing (evaluating a pain threshold and applying 5 consecutive stimulations at 110% of the electrical threshold ) over a normal area of skin at a similar dermatomal level as a previous burns injury

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: once off visit after burns group complete on healthy volunteers

secondaryOutcome.outcome: demographic data is collected using a survey
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 6 month post burn injury visit, once off visit for healthy volunteers.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Burns Group 1. Burns injury sustained approximately 6 months prior which was 10% or greater in total body surface area not affecting the area of testing (ankle and leg) bilaterally 2. Alert and orientated 3. Ability to give informed consent 4. Able to cooperate with the nerve stimulation test 5. No current pain at rest Healthy Volunteer Group 1. Alert and orientated 2. Ability to give informed consent 3. Able to cooperate with the nerve stimulation test 4. Age average age of burns group +/- 5 years.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
Burns Group 1. Patient Refusal 2. 2. Burns/scarring to either of the two lower limbs below the knee 3. Inability to provide informed consent 4. Psychotic or paranoid disease 5. Chronic pain syndrome prior to burn 6. Acute/chronic brain syndrome 7. Current opioid therapy 8. History of untreated hypertension 9. History of diabetes 10. History of peripheral neuropathy
Health Volunteer group 1. Patient Refusal 2. Inabilility to provide informed consent 3. Current or past history of psychotic or paranoid disease 4. Past history of chronic pain sydrome(s) 5. Acute/chronic brain sydrome 6. Recent (within 2 weeks) or current opioid use 7. History of untreated hypertension 8. History of diabetes 9. History of peripheral neuropathy

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Patients with previous burns injuries are subject to abnormal pain processing responses compared to people who have never been affected by severe burns. We propose to run a pilot study which will demonstrate whether patients have ongoing abnormal pain responses. This would be determined by using a form of quantitative sensory testing which evaluates the integrity of pain pathways.
